Some of the annotations are pretty well understood and map directly to
JUnit 3 concepts, so I'll just keep them here for completeness:

*	@Test - run this method as a test
*	@Ignore - do not run this test for now
*	@Before - set up data for the next test
*	@After - tear down data for the next test
*	@BeforeClass - set up supporting classes for this suite of tests
*	@AfterClass - tear down supporting classes for this suite of
tests

After that is a whole bunch of annotations that are quite new to me and
I'm trying to understand when, where, and how to use them:

*	@Rule - Mark a test attribute that extends MethodRule to affect
the test outcome (more advanced verifications)
*	@Category - Mark tests or test classes as belonging to a
category, which is used with specific test suites.  Not sure how this
works when you are invoking the tests through a build system.  For
example, turn off slow tests until we do integration etc.  At least it
is marked.
*	@RunWith(Runner.class) - Run a test suite with a particular
runner.  Enables other things like theories to work

Theories: thanks for the blog entry, it helps.  Are these meant to
verify an algorithm with several datapoints?  If not, what other uses
were they designed for?
*	@DataPoint - used with theories, marks a test attribute as data
to pass in to parameterized tests
*	@DataPoints - used with theories, marks a test attribute that is
a collection as data to pass in to parameterized tests?  Pure guess
here.
*	@ParametersSuppliedBy(ParameterSupplier.class) - used with
theories, maps datapoints to the theory tests?  Pure guess here.
*	@Theory - marks a parameterized test that is executed several
times to include all applicable combinations of datapoints
*	@TestedOn - not sure about its applicability.

Parameterized: run tests with a list of parameters.  The List of
parameters is specified by the @Parameters method.

Suites: run a suite of tests.  The set of classes is marked by
@SuiteClasses.
